comments:
Runtime provides a new content type registry that allows content sensitive
object contribution, automatic encoding identification, content specific
structured comparisons, and in the future will allow content specific editor
association (instead of file name based association only). 

Runtime itself contributes two content types: Text and XML. JDT will contribute
Java Properties. It seems there are a few content types that could be
contributed by PDE:
- plugin manifest - specialization of XML, named plugin.xml
- fragment manifest - specialization of XML, named fragment.xml
- build properties - specialization of Java properties, named build.properties

To contribute a content type does not require any code, only the proper markup
in the plugin manifest. Here is the markup that should be added:

plugin.xml:

<extension point="org.eclipse.core.runtime.contentTypes">
  <content-type id="pluginManifest" name="%pluginManifestName" 
    base-type="org.eclipse.core.runtime.xml"
    priority="high"				
    file-names="plugin.xml"
describer="org.eclipse.core.runtime.XMLRootElementContentDescriber:plugin"/>		
	
  <content-type id="fragmentManifest" name="%fragmentManifestName" 
    base-type="org.eclipse.core.runtime.xml"
    priority="high"				
    file-names="fragment.xml"
describer="org.eclipse.core.runtime.XMLRootElementContentDescriber:fragment"/>

  <content-type id="pluginProperties" name="%pluginPropertiesName" 
    base-type="org.eclipse.jdt.core.javaProperties"
    priority="high"				
    file-names="plugin.properties"/>
</extension>

plugin.properties:

pluginManifestName = Plug-in Manifest File
fragmentManifestName = Fragment Manifest File
pluginPropertiesName = Plug-in Properties File

I would suggest having the contributions above in the more fundamental plug-in
in PDE's feature (pde.core?).

More info: bug 59084.

Actually, adding the markup caused huge problems every time I opened the 
plugin.xml in the runtime workbench.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 4 0 May 18, 2004 00:51:36.669
!MESSAGE Could not create content describer for 
org.eclipse.pde.pluginManifest. Content type has been disabled.

Silly me... the describer class name actually is:
org.eclipse.core.runtime.content.XMLRootElementContentDescriber. The resulting
markup should be:

<extension point="org.eclipse.core.runtime.contentTypes">
  <content-type id="pluginManifest" name="%pluginManifestName" 
    base-type="org.eclipse.core.runtime.xml"
    priority="high"				
    file-names="plugin.xml"
describer="org.eclipse.core.runtime.content.XMLRootElementContentDescriber:plugin"/>
	
	
  <content-type id="fragmentManifest" name="%fragmentManifestName" 
    base-type="org.eclipse.core.runtime.xml"
    priority="high"				
    file-names="fragment.xml"
describer="org.eclipse.core.runtime.content.XMLRootElementContentDescriber:fragment"/>

  <content-type id="pluginProperties" name="%pluginPropertiesName" 
    base-type="org.eclipse.jdt.core.javaProperties"
    priority="high"				
    file-names="plugin.properties"/>
</extension>
